news.title: Zimbabwe set to implement “very ugly” measures against drug abuse
news.content:
By Staff Reporter

PRESIDENTIALspokesperson George Charamba has warned that the government is preparing to introduce harsh measures to curb drug abuse, cautioning that those involved in selling or using illicit substances should brace for very ugly consequences.

This comes at a time when Zimbabwe is grappling with an alarming rise in drug and substance abuse cases, particularly among young people.

Posting on one of his X handles under the pseudonym Jamwanda, Charamba wrote, Guys get warned: We are contemplating very ugly measures for those involved in peddling or consuming drugs.

It is going to be really ugly.

With the high rates of unemployment among the youth in Zimbabwe, many have turned to harmful drug use, often with minimal chances of full recovery.

Some of the most potent drugs abused by young people are homemade mixtures, including substances like sodium polyacrylate, commonly known as waterlock, which are produced in backyards.

Sodium polyacrylate is an absorbent for urine in diapers and is also found in some detergents.

Drug dealers are reportedlytaking advantage of the countrys porous borders to smuggle in drugs such as crystal meth, heroin, cocaine and cough mixtures like Broncleer, fueling the rapidly expanding drug market.

President Emmerson Mnangagwa last year launched a multi-sectoral drug and substance abuse plan to fight the scourge.

news.title: Jazzworx and Thukuthela to headline Afro-house festival in Zimbabwe
news.content:
The South African

The sensational duo Kgotso Thukuthela Dube and Kamohelo Jazzworx Monese are set to perform in Zimbabwe for the first time.

The pair will headline the 7th edition of HiNDE at Mystique Gardens in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe on 29 November.

Known for their electrifying 3-step dance house, the pair have become major forces in Southern Africasmusic scene.

Their groove-packed, polished tracks dominate streaming platforms and top The Official SA Charts, making this debut a must-see for Afro-house fans.

Sunday Worldreports that the duo cut ties with some friends and relocated after experiencing atraumatic house robbery.

Just weeks before releasing their 13-track album, armed robbers invaded their home, kidnapped Jazzworx, and held their friend and fellow musician Gobokweone GL Ceejay Lekganyane captive.

Jazzworx and Thukuthela remain relatively new in the business but have picked up valuable experience.

We are learning about the business side of the music industry. We had a dream but didnt see ourselves reaching international standards so soon, Thukuthela toldSunday World.

Our music is being recognised globally.

HiNDEhave confirmed on their social media pages that Jazzworx and Thukuthela will headline their upcoming event.

HiNDE is a recurring Afro-house music and culture event that takes place in Zimbabwe.

Since its launch in 2021, HiNDE has grown beyond a typical night out. It has become a vibrant platform where local and international DJs share the stage.

This edition promises to elevate Bulawayos house music scene even further as Jazzworx and Thukuthela bring their signature energy to Zimbabwean audiences for the very first time.

news.title: Pastor loses Budiriro home after faking illiteracy to evade repaying debt
news.content:
By Mary Taruvinga

A retired pastor who tried to evade repaying a US$22,750 loan by falsely claiming illiteracy has lost his case at the High Court, which ordered him to settle the debt and declared his Budiriro house executable.

Judges of appeal Justices Hapias Zhou and Benjamin Chikowero ruled that Pastor Stefan Pios Mumbiro knowingly signed all loan and mortgage documents binding him to businessman Collins Farai Muchada, but later attempted to take advantage of his supposed illiteracy to escape liability.

The first respondent was not illiterate. He was educated up to Grade 7, could read and write, and even successfully undertook pastoral studies, the judges said. He cannot evade responsibility by pretending not to understand what he signed.

The court condemned Mumbiros conduct, saying he had taken advantage of Muchadas trust while later seeking to hide behind claims of being duped.

Evidence before the court showed that Mumbiro willingly signed an Acknowledgement of Debt, a Power of Attorney to register a Mortgage Bond, and other loan documents, all of which were verified by a handwriting expert.

The only credible evidence on record was that adduced by the appellant himself, amply corroborated by the Questioned Document Examiner, the Acknowledgement of Debt, the Power of Attorney to Pass Mortgage Bond, the Mortgage Bond, and the Forensic Examination Report, Chikowero said.

The court said Mumbiros story fell apart under cross-examination when he admitted signing blank papers, a move the judges described as a deliberate attempt to distort facts and mislead the court.

Citing the long-standing legal principle of caveat subscriptor, the bench reminded litigants that a party to a contract is bound by his signature, whether or not he has read or understood the document.

Chikowero criticised the lower court for allowing Mumbiro to eat his cake and still have it by accepting contradictory statements about how much he borrowed.

As a result, the High Court ordered Mumbiro to repay US$22,750 plus interest and costs, and ruled that his Budiriro home, Stand 2308 of Willowvale Estate, be declared specially executable should he fail to pay.

In their judgment, the judges issued a clear warning to others attempting similar deceit.

The loud and clear message to go out from the court is: businessmen beware. If you fail to honour your contracts, dont start crying when the other party obtains an order compelling you to perform.

Mumbiro had earlier accused Muchada of being a fraudster who wants to con me of my house, but the judges found no proof of that claim.

The case originated at the Harare Magistrates Court, where Mumbiro initially won after convincing the magistrate that he was illiterate and had been duped. However, the High Court overturned that decision, ruling that Mumbiro had instead abused the courts sympathy and his position as a retired pastor to avoid his legal obligations.

news.title: Police officer jailed for extorting US$50 from motorist
news.content:
By James Muonwa

A KAROI based police officer has been sentenced to imprisonment for extorting US$50 from a motorist.

Sergeant Paul Mutingoringo Dzimbanhete (32) of Karoi Urban Police Station was slapped with 36 months imprisonment, with six months suspended for five years on condition of good behaviour. He will, therefore, spend an effective 30 months behind bars.

The State case was that between June 3 and 13, 2025, the offender confiscated a drivers certificate of competency from Olly Mcupi at a roadblock along the Karoi-Nyamambizi road and demanded US$50 for its release.

Court heard that following a complaint by Mcupis father, Sebastian Kumbirai Chinyemba, a special team from Police General Headquarters (PGHQ) set up a sting operation.

With instructions from the PGHQ team, Mcupi arranged to meet the rogue cop at TM Supermarket, Karoi, where Dzimbanhete handed back the confiscated certificate in exchange for cash while seated in a Toyota Gaia.

The police internal investigations team moved in immediatelycapturing the transaction on video. In a dramatic twist, Dzimbanhete swallowed the marked US$50 in a failed attempt to destroy evidence.

Officers, however, recovered cash and a notebook (ZRP Book 6) showing that he had improperly recorded Mcupis arrest as dangerous parking.

Court found Dzimbanhete guilty of extortion after altering the earlier preferred charge of criminal abuse of duty as a public officer.

In a statement following sentencing, the National Prosecuting Authority of Zimbabwe (NPAZ) said law enforcement agents must uphold the highest standards of integrity.

Every officer is expected to serve with honour, professionalism, and respect for the law, the NPAZ noted.

news.title: High Court dismisses sex offender’s bid to revive case over ‘crucial witness’
news.content:
By Mary Taruvinga

The High Court has thrown out an application by convicted sex offender Levison Popi, who sought to review his trial on the grounds that a key defence witness was not called.

Justice Sinabuliso Siziba, sitting at Mutare High Court, ruled that Popis chamber application, filed five months after his conviction, was an afterthought and lacked merit.

The explanation for the delay is unreasonable. It defies logic why he would obtain advice at that early stage from his inmates and neglect to inquire from his lawyer, Siziba said.

Popi was convicted on 16 December 2024 of attempted indecent assault under Zimbabwes Criminal Law (Codification and Reform) Act. His initial appeal was struck off the roll in March 2025 for being fatally defective.

He later argued that the trial magistrate had failed to explain his right to call a witness, Alice Nyanjowa, who has since died. Nyanjowa had previously stated that she was present in the room during the alleged incident but did not observe anything concerning the allegations.

But the judge found no irregularity in the lower court proceedings.

A perusal of the record indicates in no uncertain terms that the applicant was advised by the trial magistrate of his right to adduce evidence on his own and also through his witnesses. He then testified and also called two witnesses, the judge noted.

The court further stressed that it was Popis choice, not the courts or the prosecutors, to omit the deceased witness from his defence.

The prosecutor had no duty or right to choose witnesses for the applicant. He called the other witnesses and left out the very witness that he now complains of having been left out, Siziba ruled.

The application was dismissed with costs.

Popi was arrested in 2024 after he was accused of attempting to indecently assault a woman. Prosecutors alleged that he made unwanted sexual advances that fell short of full assault but still contravened Zimbabwes criminal statutes.

During his trial, Popi denied the allegations and presented two witnesses in his defence. However, the court found the complainants testimony credible and convicted him of attempted indecent assault.

On appeal, his challenge to the conviction was struck off the roll in March 2025. His latest effort, a chamber application seeking to revive the case by relying on the statement of the now-deceased witness, Alice Nyanjowa has now also failed, leaving his conviction intact.

news.title: Farmer accused of killing two women admits to tossing their bodies into pigsty
news.content:
Sowetan Live

The Limpopo pig farmer accused of killing two women who were scavenging for food on his property told the court that when he was alerted to the body of one of his victims, he panicked and left the scene until he returned the following day and put it in an empty pigsty.

He said he had expected the person who accompanied the intruders to come and collect the body. Then when they discovered the second body the following day, he and his employees also put it in a pigsty.

This is contained in an affidavit of Zachariah Johannes Olivier, which was read out in the Polokwane high court on Tuesday. Olivier denies that he intentionally killed Maria Makgato, 45 and Locadia Ndlovu, 34, in August last year then fed them to the pigs. Ndlovus husband survived the attack.

He said he had gone to the to spot where the women were shot expecting to see trespassers and he had tried to frighten them by shooting at them.

Olivier, 60, and co-accused William Musora, 50, entered the second day of the trial yesterday. They face charges of murder, attempted murder, employing an illegal immigrant who does not possess a work permit and the possession of an unlicensed firearm.

Musora, a Zimbabwean national, faces a further charge of contravention of the Immigration Act, for being in SA illegally.

On Monday, in a panicked state, I proceeded to cut up both rifles that were used to shoot the warning shots into pieces, and I disposed of such pieces as I was scared and disgusted with the rifles and what had transpired

Zachariah Johannes Olivier, farmer

In his affidavit, Olivier claims that after the discovery of the two bodies, he panicked and went home before returning the following day to destroy the guns used to shoot the two women.

On Monday, in a panicked state, I proceeded to cut up both rifles that were used to shoot the warning shots into pieces, and I disposed of such pieces as I was scared and disgusted with the rifles and what had transpired.

I never had any intention of defeating the purpose of the administration of justice. I simply panicked and acted out of an extreme level of shock.

According to Olivier, he called the police the following day as I could not deal with the situation any longer.

The state has since withdrawn charges against another farmworker, Adrian de Wet, 19, who is now a state witness. In his affidavit, Olivier claims that he was with de Wet on the night that the women were shot. De Wet, he claims, also fired shots.

Speaking to Sowetan outside court, Makgatos grieving mother said she will never forgive those who cut short her daughters life.

Why did he have to kill my child in such a brutal manner? Why did he not inform the police that people were trespassing on his farm, asked Moyahabo Mokgato.

The pensioner said she has been battling to take care of her household as well as her late daughters children aged 5, 12, 16 and 22 since Marias death.

After they murdered my child, I am now struggling, as I do not work. Im unable to provide for my family.

I cannot forgive them, she said.

During proceedings, judge Jane Ngobeni informed the two men that should they be convicted of murder, they face life in prison. If they are first offenders, the sentence wont be less than 15 years.
